Award.AwardTitle: Meeting National Needs for Hydrologists and Water Resource Engineers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This scholarship project from Oregon State University is recruiting 16 academically talented and financially needy students into Water Resource Science and Engineering. Recruitment efforts focus on underrepresented minorities and first-generation college attendees and therefore diversify the STEM workforce educated in water resources. The program is to transition students into graduate degree programs and ultimately into the STEM workforce. The funding is being used to enhance the experience of students and ensure their success. The program provides mentoring (peer and professional), cohort building and annual retreats to the students. Partnership with potential employers facilitates graduate placement in the workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

The  major goals for this project were:

  • to recruit talented students with financial need into the Water Resources Science (WRS) and Water Resources Engineering (WRE) graduate programs at Oregon State University,
  • to provide these students with an excellent education, research experiences, and a support network including professional and peer mentors, and
  • to help our graduates enter the work force.

One of the specific objectives of the award was to use these scholarships to help increase diversity in the professions of Water Resources Engineering and Water Resources Science.  First generation college students, as well as Black, Hispanic American, and Native American students are highly under-represented in both graduate engineering programs and graduate programs in the physical sciences (such as hydrology).  The availability of NSF STEM scholarships and associated tuition remission scholarships provided by the Graduate School at Oregon State University helped diversify our graduate program such that in the past three years of the program, over 20% of students enrolled in the WRE and WRS degree programs were members of underrepresented racial minorities and/or first-generation college students.

To date, ten students have completed their degrees, and another eleven students are continuing to work towards their PhD (six students) or Master of Science (five students) degrees. We anticipate that seven more students will complete their degrees in the 2018-2019 academic year, and  four more doctoral students will complete their degrees by 2020.

Our major activities have focused on recruitment of eligible applicants to the Water Resources Science and Water Resource Engineering degree programs, and engagement of the students in earning their graduate degrees. We have used special topics courses (WRS 599 Special Topics in Aquatic Chemistry) with hands-on field and lab experience to help engage students in active learning. One of the NSF STEM students continued the work begun during the course and developed this project into a chapter of her thesis.  

We have sponsored faculty-student retreats to support and build an inclusive community among our STEM Scholars, and improve faculty mentoring of students from underrepresented minorities and first-generation college students. We held two retreats for students in the NSF STEM program and their faculty mentors. The first retreat, held in 2015, focused on communication between advisors and students. The second, held in 2017, focused on promoting inclusion as well as diversity within the university.   

Over the course of this project (from October 01, 2012 to September 30, 2018), this award provided NSF STEM Scholarships which helped recruit and support 23 students (11 male, 12 female) in the Water Resource Sciences and Water Resources Engineering degree programs at Oregon State University.  All these students had significant financial need. At least half of them were the first in their families to attend college. Seven of the students were working towards the PhD, 16 were working towards the Master of Science degree.  In the final project year, September 2017 through September 2018, nine students received NSF STEM Scholarship support under this award.

The ten graduates to date have all found jobs (nine students) or internships (one student) in their professional field. The research reported in the theses and publications written by these students represents their original contributions to the field of hydrology and water resource engineering.
